page.title: 11ECOLOGY/CLIMATE.Headcorn.
page.content: This land East of{Headcorn village,} lies in the{Weald of Kent.}which is known as the "Garden of England" - famous for it's fruit, vegetables and flowers. It is sheltered by a Ridge of higher land to the North,and was once part of the great FOREST OF ANDERIDA There are still woods and coppices here and although some trees have been felled for various reasons, care is taken not to cut too many. Due to the number of{ponds}and the{River Sherway, a stream that converges with the larger{River Beult}half a mile to the South, the area is subject to damp, mists, and fog during the Autumn and Winter months. Keen North-East winds affect this part of Kent,but in Spring and Summer,milder air from the South brings warmth and showers for the growing plants and crops.
